title: Which is the best book or online article to teach me about the Age of Sail and tall ships? - Quora

response.answer_text: There are already a lot of good answers here, so I’ll second many of the recommendation. In the fiction department, you have the Aubrey-Maturin series by Patrick O’Brian following the careers of Jack Aubrey, a Royal Navy captain, and Stephen Maturin, a naval surgeon and intelligence agent. That bald description makes it sound implausible, or maybe hackneyed Rip Roaring Tales of the High Seas for Boys pulp but it isn’t. The series is more like what you would have gotten if Jane Austen and Ian Fleming had collaborated on a travel series with Joseph Conrad as editor. The series is so varied that it difficult to characterize, but calling it historical fiction pigeonholes it, it really succeeds as a just plain old fiction. The Aubrey-Maturin series succeeds on another level as well: O’Brian did his historical homework and it is a faithful recreation of the 19th century Royal Navy. Patrick O’Brian also wrote a couple of independent narratives of Anson’s circumnavigation - The Golden Ocean and The Unknown Shore - that have some of the same elements as the Aubrey-Maturin series but with different emphases. If you like the Aubrey-Maturin series, you’ll like The Golden Ocean and The Unknown Shore. In the history department. the works of N.A.M. Rodger have been recommended, and I’ll second the recommendation of The Command of the Ocean and The Wooden World: an Anatomy of the Georgian Navy. And I would add Rodger’s The Safeguard of the Sea too for a history of the Royal Navy before the 19th century. Other histories I would recommend:  Cochrane: The Real Master and Commander by David Cordingly Patrick O’Brian modelled Jack Aubrey on Thomas Cochrane. Cordingly’s biography of Cochrane is the real-life counterpart to O’Brian’s series.  Six Frigates: The Epic History of the Founding of the U.S. Navy by Ian Toll Six Frigates chronicles the construction of the first purpose-built warships of the fledgling U.S. Navy and their actions against rogue piratical states in the Mediterranean and the Royal Navy in the War of 1812.  Over the Edge of the World by Laurence Bergreen Even though the 16th century world of Magellan is vastly different than ours, Bergreen brings Magellan’s voyage to life. Some quick historical mentions: In the Heart of the Sea: The Tragedy of the Whaleship Essex by Nathaniel Philbrick; the fate of the Essex was the inspiration for Moby Dick. The Armada by Garrett Mattingly; an excellent history of the Spanish Armada. In the how-to department, there’s  Wooden Boats: In Pursuit of the Perfect Craft at an American Boatyard by Michael Ruhlman. Ruhlman doesn’t describe the building of really large sailing vessels, but many of the same techniques are still used in building small boats. Also, WoodenBoat Magazine often does features on the restoration and construction of large sailing vessels if you are interested in the nuts-and-bolts (which is probably not the right metaphor here).

Possibly not what you’re asking, but I can whole-heartedly recommend the Aubrey-Maturin series of novels by Patrick O’Brian[1] . There are 20 in all and I’ve read the whole series twice (it’s even possible to read it as one gigantic novel in 20 parts). The Russell Crowe movie Master and Commander: Far Side of the World[2] is an adaptation of parts of several of the books and is very enjoyable as far as it goes, but the originals are much more involving and give very detailed descriptions of life at sea and the challenges of handling warships in the early 19th century. They also have a lot of historical colour illustrating the attitudes and behaviour of the people, mostly men of course, who sailed in them. Utterly fascinating, but the author never talks down to the reader and uses a lot of sometimes very arcane technical jargon, which of course you can always look up (that’s what Google is for after all). I think what makes me like these books so much is the sense that the author is writing them for his own enjoyment as much as for ours. Footnotes[1] Aubrey–Maturin series - Wikipedia[2] Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)
